Article Title: "Crock of bullsh*t": Namita Thapar counters Narayana Murthy's call for longer work hours
Article Text:

A broader conversation: Work culture in transition



The debate over India's work culture and the suggestion of a 70-hour workweek has sparked significant discussion across the country. Two prominent figures from Shark Tank India , Namita Thapar and Anupam Mittal , recently shared conflicting perspectives on this topic during an interview with Humans of Bombay. Their contrasting views have fueled ongoing conversations about the balance between productivity, success, and well-being in the modern workforce.Namita Thapar, CEO of Emcure Pharmaceuticals, strongly opposed Mittal's stance, labeling his argument a "crock of bullsh*t." She argued that the expectations for founders and regular employees differ significantly, especially when financial stakes are involved."For founders and high stakeholders, who make tons of money ‚Äî go for it. Work 24 hours a day forever!" Thapar said. However, she stressed that expecting the same commitment from employees is unreasonable. She highlighted the disparity in financial incentives, citing her own experience: "When Emcure went public, it was valued at $3 billion, and my family owns 80 percent of it. Obviously, we could work 20 hours a day, which is what we all do. But the employee? My accountant, for instance, doesn‚Äôt share the same financial upside."Thapar raised concerns about the physical and mental health implications of extended work hours, particularly for employees who lack the same financial motivation as business owners. She emphasized the importance of maintaining a balanced schedule for overall well-being and long-term productivity.Anupam Mittal, founder and CEO of Shaadi.com, argued that success cannot be measured by the number of hours worked. Reflecting on his own experience working 16-hour days during his early career in the U.S., Mittal emphasized that dedication and focused effort outweigh mere time spent on tasks."I think it's a big lie being told to this generation," Mittal remarked, challenging the notion that longer hours equate to greater achievements. He advocated for prioritizing work-life "harmony" instead of adhering to rigid time commitments. According to Mittal, young professionals should be prepared to push themselves early in their careers but also recognize the importance of creating a sustainable balance.Highlighting the hybrid work model implemented at his company, Mittal revealed a 30% increase in productivity. He credited this approach for fostering both efficiency and flexibility, enabling employees to deliver better results without overextending themselves.The debate was reignited by recent comments from Infosys co-founder Narayana Murthy, who suggested that India‚Äôs youth should commit to longer work hours to boost productivity and global competitiveness. He cited historical examples from Japan and Germany, where extended work weeks played a role in post-war economic recovery.Murthy's call for a return to a six-day workweek and extended hours drew both support and criticism. Proponents view it as a necessary step to enhance India's economic output, while detractors argue it disregards the importance of work-life balance and employee well-being.The exchange between Thapar and Mittal underscores the complexity of India's evolving work culture. While both acknowledge the need for change, their views highlight differing approaches to achieving productivity and fostering professional growth.Thapar champions the idea of reasonable work limits for employees to avoid burnout and prioritize health. On the other hand, Mittal believes that extraordinary success requires dedication and effort, regardless of fixed hours.The conversation also reflects a larger trend in global work culture, as organizations grapple with finding the right balance between flexibility, efficiency, and employee satisfaction.Also read | Airtel recharge plans

Article Title: Amazon CEO to Young Professionals: Positive attitude helps greatly in success, but you need to ‚Ä¶
Article Text: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy says that an "embarrassing amount" of early career success depends on maintaining a positive attitude, particularly for professionals in their twenties. In a recent interview with LinkedIn CEO Ryan Roslansky , Jassy emphasized that while many career factors are beyond control, attitude remains firmly within one's grasp."I think people would be surprised how infrequently people have great attitudes," said Jassy, who has led the tech giant since Jeff Bezos stepped down in 2021. He noted that enthusiasm helps attract mentors and advocates, as "people want to be around positive people."However, Jassy cautioned that optimism alone isn't enough. Young professionals must back their positive outlook with concrete actions, including following through on commitments and maintaining a strong work ethic.The CEO, who joined Amazon as a marketing manager in 1997 and went on to launch Amazon Web Services , also stressed the importance of continuous learning throughout one's career. He warned against the complacency that can set in at senior levels, stating, "The second you think you know it all is the second you're really starting to unwind."Drawing from his own background, Jassy revealed that his early focus on competitive sports, including soccer and tennis, may have contributed to his business success. This aligns with research on Ivy League alumni showing that students who were heavily involved in athletics tend to achieve more senior positions and higher salaries in business careers than their non-athletic peers.Before joining Amazon, Jassy explored careers in sportscasting and music management. He ultimately helped build AWS into a crucial profit center that generated $13.5 billion of Amazon's $22.9 billion operating income by 2020, positioning him as Bezos's successor.
Article Summary: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy says that an "embarrassing amount" of early career success depends on maintaining a positive attitude. Jassy cautioned that optimism alone isn't enough. Young professionals must back their positive outlook with concrete actions, he said.

Article Title: Airbnb blocked 74,000 bookings worldwide on New Year eve in 2023, and says will follow same measures in 2024 as well
Article Text:
How Airbnb checks ‚Äòparty‚Äô booking

Planning a New Year's Eve party at an Airbnb? Think again. The company is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. This technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location. While implemented worldwide, the technology will specifically target the US, UK, Australia, Canada, France, Puerto Rico, Spain and New Zealand. Last New Year's Eve, Airbnb blocked 74,000 such bookings.High-risk bookings will be blocked or redirected to alternative accommodations. Short holiday getaways (one to three nights) in entire homes will also be restricted, and guests booking entire homes will be required to agree to a "mandatory anti-party attestation." "If a booking is identified as higher risk, the guest will either be blocked from booking, or redirected to alternative accommodations on the platform," the company said.Guests will also be required to accept mandatory anti-party attestation. "Guests who can make reservations will need to confirm that they understand that disruptive and unauthorized parties are not allowed on Airbnb, and they face suspension or removal from the platform if they violate this policy," said the company.Airbnb also has a 'Neighborhood Support Line' for local communities to report urgent issues, like a party in progress, at a home they believe is listed on Airbnb.Airbnb's efforts to curb disruptive parties started in 2019 with a ban on "party houses," followed by stricter measures in 2020 due to the pandemic. In 2022, the company permanently banned large parties worldwide following several violent incidents at Airbnb rentals, including a shooting in Pittsburgh that resulted in two deaths and eight injuries.
Article Summary: Airbnb is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. In 2024, Google once again made headlines by discontinuing several products and services. Known for its vast ecosystem of tools and platforms, Google has always embraced an experimental approach, regularly launching new projects while also sunsetting those that fail to meet its evolving strategic goals or user expectations. This year was no exception, as Google said goodbye to offerings that had carved out unique niches but ultimately fell short of the tech giant‚Äôs ambitions. From Jamboard to the Chromecast , 2024 saw the end of products that, despite their promise, could not sustain relevance in an ever-competitive market. Despite its innovative approach to enhancing team interactions, Google decided to discontinue Jamboard in 2024, citing a strategic shift towards software-based solutions that offer greater flexibility and accessibility across diverse devices.Launched in 2013, Chromecast revolutionized media streaming by allowing users to cast content from their devices directly to their televisions. However, in August 2024, Google announced the discontinuation of the Chromecast line, signaling a move towards more integrated smart TV solutions and advanced streaming devicesAs part of its Google One subscription service, Google introduced a virtual private network (VPN) in 2020, offering users enhanced online privacy by encrypting internet traffic and masking IP addresses. Consequently, Google shut down VPN by Google One in June 2024, redirecting resources to other security initiatives.Dropcam, a pioneer in Wi-Fi-enabled security cameras, was acquired by Google in 2014. Messaging platform Telegram has achieved its first-ever profit in 2024, marking a major milestone for the controversial chat app 11 years after its founding, CEO Pavel Durov announced Monday.The company's revenue exceeded $1 billion this year, nearly triple its 2023 figure of $342 million, driven by advertising and premium subscriptions. Durov is currently unable to leave France following his August arrest over allegations of enabling criminal activity on the platform.The messaging service, which claims approximately 950 million users, has expanded its monetization efforts through multiple channels. Its premium subscription service, launched in 2022, has attracted 12 million paying users at $4.99 monthly. The company has also introduced revenue-sharing for content creators, business-tier subscriptions, and a mini app store.Telegram has made progress addressing its substantial debt obligations, repaying what Durov described as a "meaningful share" of its $2 billion in bonds this fall. The company had previously discussed the possibility of going public.Despite its financial success, Telegram continues to face regulatory challenges worldwide. Several countries, including Spain , Germany, and the UK, have considered bans or sanctions over the platform's minimal content moderation and alleged spread of misinformation. The service remains banned in China, Thailand , and Iran.The company has responded to some concerns by expanding its content moderation team to over 750 contractors. Durov maintains that the platform can achieve financial sustainability while "staying independent and respecting users' rights."

Article Title: Apple App Store exposes children to harmful content despite safety claims, report finds
Article Text: Over 200 apps rated safe for children as young as four contain inappropriate content including stranger chat features, weight loss trackers, and violent games, according to a new report from child safety organizations released Monday. The 24-hour study by Heat Initiative and ParentsTogether Action reviewed 800 apps and found that problematic apps garnered more than 550 million combined downloads.The investigation uncovered widespread issues across apps rated 4+, 9+, or 12+ in categories like chat, beauty, diet, internet access, and gaming. Among the concerning discoveries were 25 chat apps enabling stranger communication with minors, apps promoting extreme dieting behaviors, and gaming apps soliciting inappropriate photos. Many apps also offered ways to bypass school and home internet filters, even while carrying ratings suitable for young children. Apple takes no legal responsibility for the veracity of age ratings," the report stated, despite the company's claims that the App Store is a "trusted place" for users. The study found nearly all weight loss and unfiltered internet access apps were approved for children aged four and above. The researchers called for several reforms, including implementation of independent third-party reviews, greater transparency in the app rating process, stronger enforcement of age ratings, and enhanced parental controls.While Apple conducts both automated and manual checks on apps and provides features like Screen Time for child protection, the company acknowledges that " App Store security measures alone can never be perfect." With nearly 2 million apps on the platform, comprehensive screening remains challenging. The report's authors emphasized that the most effective protection requires both improved app screening and engaged parenting, recommending that parents actively monitor their children's app usage and verify app safety through personal testing.The findings come amid broader scrutiny of the App Store, including a recent $1.95 billion EU fine over anti-competitive practices in March 2024. Apple has not yet commented on the report's findings.
Article Summary: Over 200 apps rated safe for children as young as four contain inappropriate content, a new report says. The investigation uncovered widespread issues across apps rated 4+, 9+ or 12+ in categories like chat, beauty, diet, internet access, and gaming. The researchers called for several reforms, including implementation of independent third-party reviews.

Article Title: US government starts another investigation targeting these Chinese technology companies
Article Text: The Biden administration opened a trade investigation into China's production of older-style semiconductors , setting the stage for potential tariffs or other trade restrictions when President-elect Donald Trump takes office in January.The probe, conducted under Section 301 of the Trade Act, targets " legacy chips " that power everyday devices from cars and household appliances to telecommunications equipment and military systems. U.S. officials warn that China's aggressive expansion in semiconductor production, backed by government subsidies, threatens to dominate global supply chains."China's policies are enabling its companies to rapidly expand and offer artificially lower-priced chips that threaten to significantly harm their market-oriented competition," said U.S. Trade Representative Katherine Tai . Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo revealed that two-thirds of U.S. products contain Chinese-made chips, with half of companies unaware of their chips' origin.The investigation will examine China's practices in producing silicon carbide substrates and other semiconductor components, with officials expressing concern that Chinese suppliers often price chips 30-50% below U.S. competitors. The Commerce Department projects China could control more than 40% of global capacity in foundational chips by 2032.China's Commerce Ministry strongly opposed the investigation, calling it "protectionist" and warning it would "take all necessary measures" to defend its interests. The ministry argued that U.S. companies dominate the global chip market and receive substantial government subsidies.The probe, which includes public hearings scheduled for March, will be handed to the incoming Trump administration for completion. The investigation could provide Trump a ready pathway to implement his proposed 60% tariffs on Chinese imports, though some industry groups urged caution about potential supply chain disruptions.
Article Summary: The Biden administration opened a trade investigation into China's production of older-style semiconductors. U.S. officials warn that China's aggressive expansion in semiconductor production, backed by government subsidies, threatens to dominate global supply chains. The investigation could provide Trump a ready pathway to implement his proposed 60% tariffs on Chinese imports.

Article Title: Christmas 2024: How and when Google started tracking Santa Claus' journey from North Pole
Article Text:

Google Santa tracker: How to use and top features

Each year, over 100,000 kids call in to track Santa‚Äôs location, while millions more follow his progress online in nine languages as he travels across the globe spreading holiday cheer.Santa's journey can be tracked using Google‚Äôs tool on iPhone, iPad or Mac by accessing the official Santa Tracking website through a web browser. The site includes a live map displaying Santa's current location, his next stop, a live video feed of his travels, and estimated arrival times for specific locations.The website also showcases photos of places Santa has already visited, a live tally of gifts delivered, and his current distance from the user's location. Article Title: Meta‚Äôs Chief AI Scientist Yann LeCun on why AI‚Äôs need to have emotions is not a requirement, but necessity
Article Text:
Representative image

AI systems will have emotions because‚Ä¶

Yann LeCun , Meta ‚Äôs Chief AI Scientist, has made a bold, or rather provocative, prediction: future AI systems will possess emotions. In a recent interview, LeCun explained that emotions are an ‚Äúinseparable component‚Äù of the design of advanced AI systems.‚ÄúSo the blueprint of AI systems that we‚Äôre envisioning, that we‚Äôre going to build over the next few years ‚Äî those AI systems will have emotions. It‚Äôs a basically inseparable component of the design of those systems,‚Äù he said while responding to a question at an interview.He argues that emotions are a natural consequence of AI agents being driven by objectives and goals.‚ÄúWhy would they have emotions? Because they will be driven by objectives,‚Äù LeCun explained. ‚ÄúYou give them a goal that they have to accomplish, a task, and their purpose is to accomplish this task, subject to guardrails that are hardwired into their design,‚Äù he added.‚ÄúAnd for them to do this, they need a number of components. The first component they need is a way to determine whether this goal that we give them was accomplished or not. And what they also need is what we call a world model. What is a world model is something that we all have ‚Äî a prefrontal cortex that allows us to imagine what the consequences of our actions. And it‚Äôs what allows us to plan a sequence of actions to accomplish a particular goal. Now if you have this ability to predict ahead of time what a sequence of action is going to produce, then you can predict whether a goal is going to be satisfied or not. And you can predict if the outcome is going to be good or bad,‚Äù LeCun added.LeCun believes that this ability to predict and react to potential outcomes will give rise to emotions in AI.‚ÄúIf you predict it‚Äôs going to be bad, you feel fear. If you predict it‚Äôs going to be good, it‚Äôs more like elation, right? So, (you‚Äôll need) the ability to predict, and then to act so as to accomplish those predictions (which) produces the equivalent of emotions. So AI systems that are smart enough, that are capable of reasoning and planning, will have emotions,‚Äù he explained.
Article Summary: Yann LeCun, Meta‚Äôs Chief AI Scientist, has made a bold, or rather provocative, prediction: future AI systems will possess emotions. He argues that emotions are a natural consequence of AI agents being driven by objectives and goals.

Article Title: Bharti Airtel added highest number of subscribers in October 2024: TRAI
Article Text: Bharti Airtel recorded the highest net wireless subscriber additions in the month of October 2024, according to the latest Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) report. Article Title: Artificial Intelligence and the Future of Work in Emerging Markets
Article Text:
More than Just Automation

Should we take the AI Leap of Faith?

What‚Äôs The

Future of Work

in the AI Era?

What does the future hold?

--- by Sajju Jain, Board Member, Entrepreneur, & Harvard Alum

Imagine, in the future, your colleague is not a person but an AI, tirelessly handling tasks with precision, completing work in seconds, and adapting to the latest industry trends before you even blink. That future isn‚Äôt a sci-fi movie plot, it‚Äôs happening right now!When considering AI‚Äôs impact on work, automation is often the first thing that comes to mind. Yet, for emerging markets , the applications are both broader and deeper. AI has evolved beyond simple task automation. It‚Äôs not just replacing human labour ‚Äì it‚Äôs creating new possibilities for development and efficiency that were once unimaginable.For example, in healthcare, several AI startups are demonstrating how they can now automatically capture and consolidate a patient's tests and scans, their prescription information, and the clinician notes. This can provide a complete patient health snapshot to improve diagnosis, treatment, and give medical professionals more time with patients.Changes are also happening at the industry level where non-traditional players are competing with traditional healthcare providers. For example, Apple takes the vast amount of data it captures daily from users and creates a 'portable health record' for them. All this will help deliver better health outcomes, and the main beneficiaries will be emerging markets where it'll help lower costs and better utilize scarce resources like medical professionals.According to Accenture, AI can add up to $957 billion current gross value added to India's economy in 2035 by boosting productivity and creating significant new economic opportunities. Every other emerging market is also rushing to include AI at a national, industrial, and organizational level.For organizations, AI provides the potential to grow more effectively, reduce operational costs, and personalize customer experiences. According to the World Economic Forum‚Äôs recent report on the future of jobs, nearly 85% of Indian employers see AI as an opportunity to generate new jobs within the next 1-5 years and enhance the quality of existing roles. However, one of the most pressing challenges they face is the skill gap. AI demands a high level of language proficiency, data literacy, and analytical skills, which are not yet widespread among their workforces.To address this, organizations across emerging markets must invest in training and upskilling programs for their teams. Governments can support these initiatives by offering both financial and non-financial support.As AI becomes more integrated into our day-to-day lives, ethical considerations and data privacy concerns will become increasingly important. The NITI Aayog‚Äôs National Strategy for AI emphasizes the need for fairness, accountability, and transparency, especially when handling customer data.This means organizations, big or small, will need to establish clear data governance policies to comply with regulations and ensure that AI applications are ethical, fair, and non-discriminatory. Creating ethical AI isn't just about avoiding risk; it strengthens relationships with all stakeholders who know that their data is in safe hands.So, by embracing AI thoughtfully and responsibly, organizations can unlock unprecedented growth, streamline operations, and foster trust with stakeholders. Embracing AI and taking the leap of faith is not just worth taking, but essential for every organization's sustained success.The rise of AI is not just reshaping how we work but redefining what work means altogether. The future of work in India and other emerging markets will require a delicate balance between leveraging AI's capabilities and nurturing the uniquely human traits that set us apart. This transition isn't just about technology - it's about preparing people and organizations to thrive in a new era.All sectors of emerging economies are seeing growing demand for roles such as data analysts, AI trainers, cybersecurity experts, ethical AI consultants, and robotic process automation specialists. Interestingly, even roles in traditional fields like marketing, finance, and operations are also evolving to include more AI focused tasks, creating hybrid job profiles that combine core expertise with AI proficiency. For those in non-technical roles, learning how to work with AI tools for all types of roles will become a valuable skill.However, as these AI tools become ubiquitous and take on more data-heavy and process-driven tasks, stakeholders will place a premium on human interactions for competitive differentiation. Higher-level skills like emotional intelligence, creativity, and collaboration will play a critical role in AI-enabled workplaces. They'll help manage complex team dynamics, better support clients, and solve problems more effectively. So, having a mindset inclined towards continuous learning and adaptability will be critical for job security in this new landscape.The AI revolution is as unstoppable as the internet revolution was. It‚Äôs best that we embrace and guide it, instead of opposing it. The future of work for everyone in emerging markets will require creating a collaborative roadmap for responsible AI adoption ‚Äì one that aligns technology with long-term goals and includes all impacted stakeholders, especially humans. Leaders across all types of organizations, both public and private, will need to work with their stakeholders to foster a culture that values continuous learning, encourages innovation, and helps their teams see AI as a tool to enhance, rather than replace, their work.
Article Summary: The rise of AI is not just reshaping how we work but redefining what work means altogether. The future of work in India and other emerging markets will require a delicate balance between leveraging AI's capabilities and nurturing the uniquely human traits that set us apart. Embracing AI and taking the leap of faith is essential for every organization's sustained success.
